text: 1 SUBTITLE Berkeley, California -1981-

head_text.subj: DISSOLVE TO ACTUAL TV NEWS FOOTAGE FROM 1981

text: A busy intersection near the UC Berkeley campus. A strang self-propelled motorized gurney whirrs into view and make its way over a pedestrian crosswalk. The passenger, MARK O'BRIEN, in his early 30s, is visible only from the neck The rest of him is covered by a blanket. He operates the gurney with a mouth control and a set of mirrors position around his head.

Mark O'Brien has been going to UC Berkeley since 1978. That's O'Brien in the motorized gurney heading for class last week. The gurney continues along a leafy promenade on the campu Passers-by just go about their normal business.

He had polio when he was 6 years old. The disease left his body crippled but his mind remained sharp and alert, and since he wanted to be a writer, Mark O'Brien entered Cal to major in English and learn his trade. We hear a voice reciting a verse of poetry as we follow M in his contraption.

Graduation Today I hear the crowd's applause Receive congratulations from my friends Today I ask if I've found a place among the rest I hope you see a man upon this stage Who studied...read..wrote, and passed the test In cap and gown, diploma on my chair THE SCENE CHANGES to the interior of a large auditorium. graduation ceremony is in progress.  Suddenly, everyone i the hall, GRADUATES, their FAMILIES, ACADEMICS and OTHERS rise to their feet as Mark, in his gurney, buzzes across stage, a mortar board hung on one of the handles. 1A.
And so, Mark O'Brien graduates from Cal, one of 250 English majors to receive degrees today.

The DEAN steps forward, congratulates Mark and places a diploma on his blanket. The gurney makes its way across t rest of the stage to thunderous applause. THE SCENE CHANGES BACK to the campus exterior. The news reporter talks to camera.
If this report tells us anything, it is that a disability is not necessarily a handicap. In the background, Mark's family and friends are gathered round him in a jubilant mood.
Mark O'Brien teaches us that courage and perseverance overcome obstacles. With Mark O'Brien at UC Berkeley, Bill Hillman, Channel Five Eyewitness News.
Classic shot of the illuminated Golden Gate Bridge.

2 It is about 4.00 a.m. All is quiet. We follow a mean-look alley cat to the front of a modest, ground-floor apartmen It pauses, then slinks round the side, onto a ledge and i through a partially-opened window.

3 The cat comes through the window, hops onto the floor and quickly finds a nice little plate of food scraps that has been set out specially. As it settles down to its meal, w become aware of a heavy and regular sound, like a ship's pump, coming from somewhere close-by. In the center of the room is an object that looks like a from a `50s sci-fi movie. A human head protrudes from one end. The object is an iron lung, and its purpose is to ke its occupant, Mark O'Brien, breathing. Every 4.5 seconds, pump mechanism creates a vacuum inside, forcing Mark's ch to expand and suck in air. He is fast asleep.

Breathing Look you This most excellent canopy, the air, Presses down upon me At 15 pounds per square inch A dense, heavy, blue-glowing ocean. Teasing me with its nearness and immensity. And all I get is a thin stream of it. A finger's width of the rope that ties me to life. Having now eaten its fill, the cat has a good scratch, th wanders over to the iron lung.

It hops up onto the small platform that supports Mark's h and slides itself along his face, once this way, once the other way, then jumps on top of the iron lung and walks i length. Through the portholes, we just make out the shape Mark's bent, undersize body.  Suddenly, Mark's nose twitc He opens his eyes and grimaces.
Shit! His face continues to contort as he tries to cope with th terrible itching.  He shakes his head violently, then sto suddenly and closes his eyes. We hear his thoughts.

Okay, just focus. Now, scratch with your mind, okay, your mind, scratch with your mind... After a couple more nose twitches, he settles down. It se to have worked. In his peripheral vision, Mark can see th cat making itself comfortable in a corner chair, one of t only other pieces of furniture in the room. The first hin of dawn start to appear through the curtains. They illuminate a large framed portrait of the Virgin Mary han on the wall.   Mark acknowledges it.
Good morning. Sunlight streams in, making the picture look truly sacred
4 JOAN, a solid but slovenly woman in her late 30s, walks u Mark's front door, takes a key from her purse and lets herself in.
5 She comes in.
Good morning. Mark does not immediately acknowledge her.
You're late.
The center of the iron lung, basically a thin mattress, h been slid out, and Joan is in the process of giving Mark bed bath. He is frail and helpless.
There is a look of resentment in his eyes as this apparen unfeeling woman exercises total control over him, at leas temporarily.

Joan I swear this was one crazy bitch Who'd swing me about enough to scare me, But careful enough so she could say: "Now what was all the yelling about? You polios are screamers. Always were." I didn't say a word, but typed my skinny novel in my head, And thought about revenge. In the course of washing his private parts, Mark has an involuntary erection. Joan gives him a shriveling look. H feels belittled and humiliated.
Mark is on his side, his trousers are on and she is butto up a bright red shirt. It is an awkward business. They do in silence, avoiding eye contact as much as possible.

head_text.subj: EXT. STREET OUTSIDE MARK'S PLACE. DAY

text: 6 Joan pushes Mark along in a gurney, similar, but slightly different from the one in the news clip. There are no mir and no motor, just an oxygen tank, a tube and a mouthpiec just next to Mark's mouth. Most of him is covered with a colorful blanket. The whole thing is a sports-coupe versi of his iron lung.
Would you mind if I asked you a favor?
You need help moving furniture? She has no apparent sense of humor.
I need an advance on my pay, like two weeks. That's not a big ask, is it? Mark looks rightfully shocked.
What if you don't last another two weeks?
He gives her a look, and means it. We hear his thoughts.

Joan never failed to put me in a crappy mood. It was also a drag that I was no longer allowed to use my other gurney, the self-propelled one. It had caused a couple of spectacular accidents. They turn a corner and approach a church.
Basically, in spite of all the mirrors, I couldn't see where I was going.
Joan pushes Mark's gurney into the sanctuary.
7 FATHER BRENDAN is giving a sermon. Mark listens with satisfaction. There are not many others there.

The Apostle Luke tells us that when Elizabeth spoke to Mary, the baby in her womb leapt - "For lo, as soon as the voice of thy salutation sounded in mine ears, the babe leaped in my womb for joy". So Mary's fear and apprehension slowly gave way to pride and purpose. Elizabeth saw the greatness in Mary. "Blessed art thou among women". Elizabeth, pregnant herself with St. John, felt the power of this wondrous woman. It was Elizabeth, and her absolute faith, that gave Mary the courage she was lacking, and she gave thanks saying: "My soul doth magnify the Lord, and my spirit hath rejoiced in God my Saviour". May the spirit of the Lord be amongst you and remain with you always. Mass is over. PEOPLE come up to Mark and place a hand on head or chest and say, "God bless you." In the background can also hear Father Brendan.
May the peace of the Lord be with you.
And also with you.

Mark waits alone in a tiny chapel off to the side of the church. He turns his head, takes a suck on the mouthpiece his portable respirator, then looks around at the impress stained glass windows. The expression on Mark's face is t of a true believer.

I'm definitely a true believer. But I believe in a God with a sense of humor. A wicked sense of humor. One who created me in His own image. Father Brendan enters. There is an awkward short moment w he realizes that there is no point in offering to shake hands. For no good reason, he nods instead.
Hello. I'm Father Brendan. I don't think we've met.
No, we haven't. I'm Mark O'Brien. I knew Father Seamus very well. I'm sorry that he's not here any more.
As are many others. I'm going to do my best to fill his shoes. I understand you'd like me to hear your confession.
Yes, I would. By the way, I enjoyed Mass. I liked your tone. Father Brendan is not sure how to take this.
Thank you.
You don't believe absolute privacy is an essential part of the confessional, do you?
No, I do not. I believe sincerity is the most essential part.
I told my attendant to come back in half an hour. Is that okay?
Yes, take your time. I'm in no rush.
Did Father Seamus say anything to you about me?
No one said anything to me about you.
I can be a bit time consuming, but I'm worth the trouble. Father Brendan breaks a smile for the first time.
I'm here for you Mark.
Look, this is not exactly a confession. I haven't yet done the deed. I was hoping to sort of get a quote in advance. Father Brendan sits down.
Tell me what's on your mind.
The most immediate thing on my mind would be my attendant, Joan. I'm thinking of getting rid of her. It's an evil thought, but I can't help it.
Is she dishonest, or incompetent?

No, neither of those. She looks at me the wrong way. It's that you- need-me-more-than-I-need-you look. I'd like to show her she's wrong, just for the evil satisfaction it will give me. Is that a sin, Father?
Well, it obviously troubles you.
Yes, it troubles me a lot. Because maybe it's really a power trip. Me against her. Me against the world.
I really wouldn't worry too much about that. The question is whether you like having her around.
I can't stand her.
Then get rid of her. If I were in a position to choose, I'd get someone nice. Even it was a power trip.
Then I have your blessing to fire her?
Unofficially, yes.
That's good enough for me.
Please, if ever you feel I can be useful, do let me know. It was a pleasure talking with you.
Same here.

8 We see a pencil eraser on the end of a stick slowly tappi the keys on an electric typewriter. At the other end of t stick, which is about a foot long, is Mark, manipulating adeptly with his mouth. There is a white index card in th typewriter on which he is typing a job notice. We see the first word. "POET"
9 A community notice board. A young female hand reaches in takes an index card off the board. The card reads:

head_text.subj: POET/JOURNALIST REQUIRES ASSISTANT WITH ADVANCED SENSE OF

text: We see Amanda's face as she smiles. She is in her early 2
Amanda would have been a pretty girl to touch, to hold, to kiss, to take to bed.
11 Mark is in his iron lung. Amanda sits in a stiff chair a feet away, being interviewed. Rod is working in the kitch Mark's poem continues.
Her perfect, pale skin, Her Tudor court face Her strong, fleshy legs Drove me into ecstasies of despair. Mark asks a question.
Do you have any experience?
No, none at all.
That sounds perfect. Mark stares at her lovingly.
12 From Mark's POV, Amanda slides him out of the iron lung. is her first time, and it is an awkward business.
How long can you stay out?
Three or four hours. Depends whether I'm having fun. 12A   INT. MARK'S PLACE.
It is some time later. Amanda is giving Mark a massage. W enormous satisfaction, he feels her curvy parts moving ar him and sometimes pressing against him. He also gets a bi eye view of her breasts.
She'd count in French before lifting me, un, deux, trois, quatre! I'd scream Tugged by her athletic arms From the everlasting gravity.
14 Mark, on a blanket, is on an outing with Amanda, Matt and another COUPLE. They are playing Scrabble.
MARK (V.O.)
She took me on a picnic once, With her boyfriend and another couple. Lust crackled in the air between those twentyish people. Amanda is clearly paying more attention to Mark than to M MARK (V.O.)
What did the boyfriend think? That I was in his way? I'm always in somebody's way, I thought, the sun in my eyes.
We sense Mark's deep satisfaction as he closes his eyes a the sun warms his face.
As she glided through crowds of lives She couldn't leave me lying there Dried out bubble gum stuck on the underneath of existence.
13 Amanda and her boyfriend MATT, are sharing the tub.
Do you touch him?
I do everything. Any other questions?
You don't have to be so defensive. I'm not about to get jealous.
Why not? He's a much nicer person than you are. She gets out of the bath suddenly.
15 Amanda is shaving Mark.
What does your boyfriend think of me?
He's an asshole. It doesn't matter what he thinks of you.
I'm interested in the opinion of an asshole.
He thinks you're some kind of Svengali, and that you're going to hypnotise me into your cult.
He's right.

He says he can already see changes. She finishes shaving him and cleans him up. His eyes feas every detail of her face. Cut to somewhere at night, Amanda is giving Mark a pole dancing demonstration, complete with disco beat and mirro ball lighting.
So with her gentle fearless heart She took me in. I thrived in her garden And wanted more.

head_text.subj: EXT. STREET NEAR CLOTHING STORE. DAY

text: Amanda wheels Mark towards a clothing store.
16 Amanda is wheeling Mark in his gurney around the store, stopping from time to time to take something down from th shelf. She picks out a shirt.
This you must have. As she leans over to show it to him, Mark doesn't seem to listening. He whispers to her.

I love you. She says nothing and gives the faintest of smiles, then p the shirt back. They continue round the store in thoughtf silence and avoid eye contact with each other. We sense f the looks on their faces that this moment spells the end beautiful friendship.
18 Mark and Father Brendan are huddled together in the littl chapel.
Did she reciprocate your feelings?
She didn't seem to. 11A.
Sometimes people can be very shy about their emotions.
Well, in case she didn't get it the first time, I told her again that I was in love with her, and wanted to marry her, thinking it might swing things.
Did it?
Yes. She left. They sit in silence for a while. Father Brendan seems to at something of a loss.

I wish I knew what to say. I mean, welcome to the human race. Every day someone breaks someone else's heart. And as I said, I'm here for you. I just wish I had something more useful to offer. All I have are these vague ideas about life and death that priests are equipped with. Have you ever thought of discussing your feelings with a therapist?
Not as yet. Father, I think I need a hug. After a moment of surprise, Father Brendan rises to the occasion. He seems to know how to move Mark gently and efficiently. They hug.
19 Rod is in the front yard picking up the newspaper. He see VERA, Chinese, mid-20s, a sensible type, approaching Mark front door.
Hi. Vera?
Yes. He offers his hand.
I'm Rod. I do four to twelve.
20 Vera sits in the same spot where Amanda was interviewed, without the same aura, although she is far from ugly.
Have you had any experience?
Some. She is reserved and unsmiling. Mark seems disinterested i the whole process. The phone rings. They both look at it.
Would you get that, please. Vera picks up the phone and answers a little hesitantly.
Hullo. After a few moments, she turns to Mark.
It's Sandy, from Pacific News Service.
Could you press that button and put it on the speakerphone. She does as she is asked with perfect efficiency.
Hi, Sandy.
Hi, Mark, how you doing?
I'm good. I have a new attendant. She answered the phone. Her name's Vera.
Welcome, Vera.
Thank you.

Mark, we've gotten sponsorships to do a series on sex and the disabled and we'd like you to do some interviews in the Berkeley area. Could you do that? Say in the next week or so? Mark is momentarily taken aback.
Why now?
No particular reason. If you're working on something else, then we can talk about it later.
No, now is fine.
21 Vera wheels Mark towards his first interview. The more we Vera, the more we like her.
There was no denying it. A door had opened which I could not close, and in invisible writing it said: "Do not enter".
22 We see the slowly rotating reels of a portable cassette recorder. We hear a female voice.
Some positions, like that one, are pretty much impossible. Carmen, early 30s, is a paraplegic in a wheelchair. She i pretty and animated, and has full use of her hands.

I don't know if you can quite visualize it. It's called a lateral, or sideways reverse cow- girl. It is obvious that Mark cannot visualize it. Although she doesn't give much away, we sense that Vera can. 14A.
Don't worry about it then. It's just a question of depth of penetration. (MORE)

To some people it's really important, like my partner, for example. It's not such a big deal for me. I get just as excited when he licks my nipples, if and when he bothers to do it. Mark looks troubled.
I think the tape's about to run out. At that very moment, there is a click, and the tape runs Vera flips the tape over, sets it running in record mode, takes her place again behind Mark's gurney.
Do you want to keep going?
Uh, I think I've actually got enough to work on. Thanks.
Get back to me if you need anything else. Oh, and let me give you Greg's phone number. He's full of stuff you wouldn't think was possible.
23 Rod vacuums the floor while Mark taps away on his typewri Mark looks troubled.
We hear voices.
Okay, shall we start?
Sure. We hear the cassette recorder click on.
Greg is a handsome quadriplegic. Vera is there with Mark.
Oral sex is a matter of taste. Mark doesn't get it. Vera, as usual, is impassive.

And one thing that really works in my favor is that I smoke so much weed that my taste buds are pretty jaded. This gives me a great deal of stamina in the tongue department, and stamina is key in cunnilingus.
24 The alley cat creeps in through the open window. Mark wat it approach from his iron lung.
Who are these people? I feel like an anthropologist interviewing a tribe of headhunters. The cat seems to understand.
25 A lady with a crisp voice answers the phone.
Good morning. UCSF. On the other end of the line, Mark tries to control the shakiness of his voice.
Uh, may I please speak to someone in the Center on Sexuality and Disability, please. A pause.
I'm sorry sir, the Center on Sexuality and Disability has been shut down.
26 Mark looks immensely relieved. He closes his eyes.
Thank God.
Sir?
I'm sorry to have bothered you.
It's no bother...Sir, before you go, I can give you a phone number for one of the therapists who used to work there. Would you like that?
Mark hesitates. He winces under the strain of having to m a decision.
Sir, are you there?
29 It is a typical, modern, multi-purpose office building. hear the sounds of grunting, bumping and clanging.

30 There is something of a commotion going on at one of the elevators.  Vera, and a small, well-meaning CROWD, are tr to get Mark and his gurney inside. It will not fit horizontally.  As they angle it up, Mark begins to panic.
It won't fit. It's not going to fit. Let's go back.
A muscular LATINO guy reassures him.
Hey, it's fine. We got you. This is going to work just fine.
Vera guides him.
The top has to go over to the left.
MARK
I don't feel so good about this. Let's forget it. The Latino guy takes no notice.   Vera is flushed and ang
Look, do you want to see this woman or not?
No! One more heave and the gurney goes in with a jolt.
Aah!
Well, it's too late. The elevator doors close.
31 Laura, a well-dressed, attractive woman in her late 30s, in a chair a few feet from Mark. His gurney takes up most the available space in the room.
Did you ever discuss sex with your parents?
No. That would have been unthinkable.
Why?

That's the way they saw the world. It wasn't just that polite people didn't think about sex. No-one did. It was never discussed. As far as they were concerned, there was nothing down there. Laura listens. She is pretty in a dark, angular way. A ph on her desk rings.
Sorry about that. She walks over to it, pushes a button, then comes back. S has a noticeable limp.
What's that from?
Cerebral palsy.
MARK
You'd hardly notice. LAURA
People notice. It's not easy, the whole thing, attracting a guy, dating, sex, all very problematic. MARK
I find that hard to believe in your case. LAURA
Well, you better believe it. MARK
So, what sort of chance do you give me? LAURA
Of achieving your romantic fantasy? Very small to minute. MARK
Look, there's no need to pull any punches. You can be as direct as you like with me. She smiles. LAURA
Mark, I'm just a humble sex therapist. I try to help people with sex problems that can be addressed. Your problem, I understand, is that you have never had sex. MARK
That's correct. LAURA
Would I be correct in assuming you're unable to masturbate? MARK
Correct. LAURA
Has anyone done it for you? MARK
No. LAURA
Have you ever asked anyone?
Not specifically. I asked someone to marry me. She declined. Does that come close to masturbation?
You know, being with the person you love is not the only way of expressing yourself sexually. There are people called sex surrogates.
Oh?
Psychotherapists and psychiatrists are not allowed to have sex with their clients, even if it seems like a good idea. Sex surrogates don't have that limitation.
Would this be covered by my medical benefits?
Unfortunately, no. You'd have to pay the full fee, whatever that was.
So, basically, I would be paying for sex.

Yes Mark, you would be paying for sex. But the person you would be paying is not a hooker. She is a highly trained and sensitive professional, who is not motivated by money. Just as I'm not. In fact, you can think of a surrogate as an extension of me. Do I seem like a hooker to you? Mark thinks.
Mark comes back to reality.
What sort of cost would I be looking at?
It depends how many sessions you need.
Say, one, just to try it and see if I like it.
I'm sorry, it doesn't work that way. It's a process. You have to be patient with yourself. There can be quite a lot of talking involved.
I've set aside $500. Do you think that would cover things?
Oh yes, that's ample. So, what do you think?
32 Rod wheels Mark into the church.
33 Mark waits in the little side chapel. Father Brendan ente
Hi, good to see you. How are things?
Things are sort of confusing at the moment. I would appreciate your advice, as a friend, if you know what I mean. Father Brendan sits down on the end of a pew next to Mark
Sure, and I understand what you mean.
Do you remember at one point you suggested I might see a therapist?
Yes.
Well, one way or another, it's a long story, I ended up seeing a therapist, a particular sort of therapist, a sex therapist.
Uh-huh.
My penis speaks to me, Father Brendan. Sometimes I ejaculate during a bed bath in front of my attendant.
MARK (CONT'D)
All I feel is shame and mortification, while other men, apparently, get pleasure. I'm sorry if I sound angry. FATHER BRENDAN
Don't worry about it. Go on. Mark pauses to take a few breaths on his oxygen mouthpiec then goes on. MARK

This therapist suggested I could work with a sexual specialist, have sex with someone known as a sex surrogate, who would be sensitive to my special needs. I've been giving it some thought. Father Brendan interrupts him. FATHER BRENDAN
Hold on. What do you mean "have sex"? MARK
Well, I don't really know how to describe... FATHER BRENDAN
Sorry, that wasn't what... I mean, are we talking about sexual intercourse? MARK
I think so. FATHER BRENDAN
Outside marriage? MARK
I did do my best on the question of marriage. Father Brendan shakes his head with concern. FATHER BRENDAN
What is the difference between this sexual specialist and a common prostitute? MARK
I don't know, but I think there's a difference. 23A.
How do you know she's not some hooker gussied up as a social worker, who's just going to rob you?
I trust what my therapist said about her.
How old are you?
Thirty-eight.
Why exactly now?
I never had any spare cash before. That's a major factor, and I'm probably getting close to my use-by date.
And this is what you want my advice about? Fornication?
Your advice as a friend.
And do I have the casting vote, so to speak?
Let's say I value your advice just as much as I do the therapist's.
You're serious, aren't you?
I think sex is a serious matter. It's one of the most persistent themes in the bible. (MORE)
So, is it possible for me to know a woman, in the biblical sense, and do I want to find out?
And you want my opinion?
Please. Father Brendan contemplates for a few moments. He looks u the statue of Jesus, then makes a decision.
I know in my heart that He'll give you a free pass on this one. Go for it.
What?
I said, go for it.
Really?
If you feel up to it. Do you feel up to it?
To tell the truth, I'm scared.
Then we should pray. Father Brendan and Mark pray together.
Sweet Jesus, Mark and I sit at your feet and pray that You bless this little journey, this one small step for a man.
38 ROD is wheeling Mark along in his gurney.
I really feel proud of myself, imposing on someone I hardly know, to fornicate in their home.
Get over it. It's perfectly normal. They arrive at CARMEN'S PLACE.
39 Carmen, in her electric wheelchair, is the woman Mark had earlier interviewed. She pushes a button on a remote cont which opens concertina double-doors, which reveal an adja bedroom.
Tada! The bed itself is set at a perfect height for someone in wheelchair or gurney. The room has been decked out with flowers, candles and incense.
Wow! Carmen points to the bedside table.
There are all sorts of useful things in that drawer there, if you guys feel like exploring. Mark doesn't even begin to get it.
No, I'll bring my own sheets, towels and anything else we need.
No, no. Everything will be provided. I'm honored that you asked me. It'll be great karma for the house.
40 Rod is wheeling Mark back home.
Great karma for the house. My God, the pressure, already. I can't stand it.
44 We are outside an old-style wooden house with a Volvo wag parked in front. A phone rings.
45 We hear the sound of sneakers on a wood floor. TONY, an adolescent with a pony tail picks up the phone.
Hey, this is Tony. He listens, then looks away from the phone and shouts.
Cheryl!
What is it?
Phone! He talks into the mouthpiece.
She's coming. CHERYL arrives. She is in her mid-30s. She grabs the phon puts her hand over the mouthpiece and glares at Tony.
I'm not your girlfriend. When someone calls, particularly someone you don't know, you can use the word 'Mom'.
Tony glares back. Cheryl takes off her right earring.
Hullo, this is Cheryl.
Hi, it's Laura.
I haven't heard from you in a while. How are you?

Pretty well. Look, I called to ask how you would feel about working with a severely disabled client. Suddenly, Cheryl notices that Tony has opened the refrigerator and is drinking straight out of the orange j bottle.
Hold on a moment, please. She covers the mouthpiece of the phone.
Hey, cut that out! He takes no notice. She puts the phone down and moves tow him. He closes the fridge door and runs.
46 Mark is having a bed bath. His shoulders and neck are cov with soap suds. Rod is washing his back. The phone rings.
Would you get it please?
Sure. Rod eases Mark back onto the rubber mattress and goes to answer the phone.
Hullo, Mark O'Brien's phone. He switches it to speaker so Mark can hear.
Hi, this is Cheryl Cohen-Greene. May I speak to Mark?
Rod holds the phone toward Mark like a question. Mark's f looks drained of blood.
Just one moment, please. Rod switches the phone off speaker.
What am I doing here? Yes or no? Make up your mind. Mark hesitates, then nods weakly. Rod puts the phone back speaker.
Hullo, this is Mark.
Hi, Mark. I'm Cheryl. Laura called to introduce you. I understand you'd like to meet. Is that right? Mark can hardly speak. He eventually forces the sound fro his throat.
Uh, yes.
I could see you on the seventeenth, at eleven o'clock. Would that be any good for you?
Uh, yes, I think that would be fine for me.
Hey, where you from?
Boston. You?
Salem. Small world.
Wouldn't want to paint it.
47 Cheryl is on the phone, holding the receiver with one han while she puts away groceries with the other.
We'll be talking for a while to begin with. Then, if you agree, we can also start doing some body awareness exercises in your first session.
48 The iron lung pumps away. Mark is alone. He stares at the picture of the Virgin Mary.
Holy Mother of God, what are "body awareness exercises"?

head_text.subj: EXT. STREET OUTSIDE MARK'S PLACE. DAY

text: 49 Vera lets herself in.
50 Vera holds up two shirts for Mark to see, a dark red and light blue.
Which one? Mark is lying on his side, shirtless. His face is even mo grim than when we last saw it.
Doesn't matter.
Will you stop acting as if you're going to your own execution.
I'm not acting.
51 Vera wheels Mark to his doom.
Try and think of something else. Baseball, for example. That's what they usually tell boys to do.
Who are "they"? Vera rings the front doorbell. They wait.
She's forgotten. Vera says nothing. She rings the bell again.
My God, she's forgotten, or she's gotten the date wrong. Okay, we might as well turn round and go back. Come on, let's go.
She hasn't forgotten. From inside the house, we hear the faint buzz of an elect wheelchair approaching. The door opens. Mark closes his e in despair.

53 Vera eases Mark onto the bed, positioning him so that he see the doorway. As a finishing touch, she dabs a little cologne behind his ears, then puts the mouthpiece of his respirator within easy reach. Carmen picks up her bag and wheels herself to the door.
Okay, I'm going. I'll be back some time after one. If I'm not here, just let yourselves out.
Bye.
(weakly)
Bye.
Have fun. She lets herself out.
What's the time?
Twelve after eleven.
I think there's a strong possibility she's had second thoughts.
Mark, please calm down.
And if she does arrive, she would be perfectly within her rights to turn around and run.

The doorbell rings. They stare at the door. Vera finally over and opens it. Silhouetted against the light is Chery with a substantial bag. She could be the Avon lady. She h light blouse, light skirt and her long hair is loose. CHERYL

You said yourself, it's not supposed to get personal.
That's another thing altogether. What I want to know is where do you get off opening my mail?
It was scented. I assumed it was just junk mail.
Even less reason to open it. Where is it? Give it to me.
You're not getting it.
This is absolutely none of your fucking business.
You're still not getting it. I threw it out.
You didn't.
I fucking did. Tony arrives home from school. As he comes in, his parent fall silent. He realizes he has walked in on an argument. looks at both of them.

What's up? A LITTLE LATER. The three of them are sitting round the dining table eating dinner in total silence. The hostilit between Cheryl and Josh is palpable. When Josh finally do speak, he addresses Tony.
Would you please ask your mother to pass the salt?
Cheryl, would you please pass the salt? Cheryl glares at Tony and goes on with her meal.
116 Cheryl is at the dining table, with her recorder and file front of her, plus a late-night snack.

Mark appears to be indulging in typical transference behaviour. This is not unusual after first successful intercourse, but I think he is especially susceptible. He cannot help seeing me as the multi- functional, all-purpose woman, mother, sister, schoolmistress, whore, lover and best friend. At the same time, his anxiety about sexual performance has diminished.
117 Josh crawls into bed with Cheryl. She is still awake. He snuggles up to her.
I'm sorry. I really upset you before.
No, you didn't. I'm fine.
You sure?
Yes, I promise.
Really?
Yes, I've come around to your point of view. You were right. You're generally right about these things.
It was quite a nice poem. I mean, nothing astounding, but heartfelt, at least.
Josh, I need to go to sleep. Everything's good.
Okay. Good night. They kiss.
118 Cheryl rummages around in the kitchen garbage. She finds nothing. She storms off to the laundry, flings open a cupboard, pokes around and comes up with a flashlight.

119 Cheryl makes her way to the end of the yard. Holding the flashlight between her teeth, she rummages around in the outdoor trash bin. Finally, she finds what she is looking for. An envelope. She takes the poem out of the envelope reads it.

Let me touch you with my words. For my hands lie limp as empty gloves. She goes over to the back steps, sits down and continues reading. She puts it back in the envelope and walks back inside th house. She is visibly affected.

head_text.subj: EXT. STREET OUTSIDE MARK'S PLACE. DAY

text: 122 From behind, we see Vera wheeling Mark in his gurney. ANO FEMALE FIGURE creeps up beside Vera and whispers in her e all unbeknownst to Mark. The other female figure takes ov from Vera, who trails along, a few feet behind. Mark rema unaware. He has a new and different-looking shirt, even m out there than the previous one?
Do you think she'll like the shirt?
I like it. Does that count? Mark can barely believe it.
Amanda?
123 They are stopped at a park bench. Vera is hovering in the background, out of earshot.
It's been a while.
I know. I'm sorry. I'm going to Germany. I wanted to say goodbye to you before I left.
Why are you going to Germany?
To study German.
For how long?
One or two years maybe. But we should keep in touch.
But why go to Germany? It's the only place in the world where humor is actually forbidden. She laughs, then smiles quietly, then touches him.
You could always make me laugh. I love you, Mark. I really do. Mark's face is a picture of anguish and confusion.
Really?

Yes, I love you, but not in that way. I love you, but I'm not in love with you. Blah, blah, blah. You know how it goes. Mark lets out a deep, meaningful sigh. For a time, he and Father Brendan maintain a respectful silence.
I think it's great what you're doing with this surrogate lady. She leans over and kisses Mark on the lips.
It could have been you.
It could have been, but it wasn't.
I had this faint hope that she would show the merest hint of jealousy. It shows you how naive I am.
The fact that I was no longer a virgin, that I was a `made man', so to speak, made no difference to her at all.
127 Cheryl's car is in the parking lot. We see her draw the blinds.
128 Clerk takes two beers from a mini-bar and hands one to Ve
Thanks.
You want to go out some time?
No, I don't think so.
What, your boyfriend?
No.
Your parents?
No, I'm busy, that's all. What's wrong with this, anyway? We're having a nice time, aren't we?
It's okay.
Or do you have things to do? I can go for a walk if you're busy and come back later.
No, no, stay. Is this going to be a regular thing?
What?
The therapy.
I don't know. I'm not the therapist.
What sort of a therapist is she, really?
I told you the first time, she's a sex therapist. The clerk looks at her closely. She appears to have a completely straight face.
Today they're working on simultaneous orgasm.
What's that?
129 Mark and Cheryl are in bed, their faces close.
Boy, am I glad to see you.
Don't you say that to all the girls?
Yes, but I always mean it. They kiss. Then Cheryl's head slides down and disappears view.
Remember about the breathing. Concentrate on breathing out rather than in. Think of anything neutral. Sky, water, trees, ships, music, nothing too dramatic. Mark closes his eyes.
The first time, I really didn't know what was going on. Technically it all happened, but nothing really happened in my head.
This time it did, and my head has never experienced anything like it before. Of course, I ignored Cheryl's advice about having neutral thoughts.
131 Amanda is giving Mark a pole dancing demonstration, compl with disco beat and mirror-ball lighting.
133 Mark opens his eyes and looks up at Cheryl. She seems div His excitement increases. We hear the change in his breathing. Also in her breathing.
134 The expression of elation on Mark's face morphs dramatica into something else.
Then afterwards, there was this moment, this glimpse of an awful sadness to come. Father Brendan closes his eyes and nods knowingly.
137 The Volvo is parked out front. The envelope is still on t dash.
138 Cheryl is dictating.
Mark achieved an erection as soon as I started to suck on him. He did the controlled breathing, as I had suggested, and I was able to get on top and guide him in quite easily.
139 We see Mark's face from Cheryl's POV. His eyes are still closed.
Is it in? Is it really in?
Yes, it's really in. We hear Mark's thoughts.
I couldn't believe it. We hear the sound of typing.
140 Mark is in his iron lung, typing. At the top of the page, can see the title of the piece: "On Seeing a Sex Surrogate" Page 8.
I was finally there. Too soon, I came. But she kept holding me inside her. Then a look of pleasure brushed lightly over her face...
141 We see Cheryl's face from Mark's POV. It is as beatific a have ever seen it.
... as though an all-day itch were finally being scratched. Letting me go, she put her hands down on the bed by my shoulders and kissed my chest. This act of affection moved me deeply.
Cheryl's actions follow Mark's description.
142 Mark is with Father Brendan.
I almost wept. No-one had ever kissed me there before. It was so unexpected and so natural.
143 Cheryl's lips move away from Mark's chest. She kisses him the lips, light and lingering. As soon as there is enough space between them, he whispers to her.
I love you. She whispers back.
I love you, too.
Did you come?
Yes.
144 Cheryl continues dictating.

Mark is breathing well and learning to pace himself. There is no real physical impediment to a variety of sexual activities, given the right sort of partner. His deeper emotional needs are outside the scope of my potential involvement. Cheryl pauses, then goes on.
As anticipated, this was the final session. Tony appears. He seems to have some understanding of what going on. He and Cheryl hug.
145 They are still in the same intimate position. 75.
What happens when...
What happens when what?
When people become attached to each other.
What people?
Just people. What's the chemistry of it all? When people are attracted to each other.
Are you attracted to me?
We're just talking hypothetically.
Hypothetically, they write poems, they have sex.
And what happens next?
After poetry and sex? Nothing or everything. The rest is by negotiation, as it were.
What do you mean?
I mean, you can just leave it at love and attraction, or you can make things complicated. As most people do.
Have you?
Oh, yes. 76.
146 The clerk looks bored. Vera looks at the time. She seems little anxious.
Can I use that phone to call the room?
Sure.
149 The phone rings, Cheryl picks it up.
Cheryl, already dressed, is getting Mark dressed. She doe every button of his shirt lovingly.
What shall we do next time? Any requests?
Mark doesn't answer.
Mark?
I'm thinking.
She finishes buttoning him up in silence. A strange feeli a kind of chill that Cheryl senses, pervades the atmosphe
We have two sessions left, is that correct?
That's right. Or...
Or, what?
Or, we could stop now.
You mean, make this the last session?
Yes.
There is a pregnant pause. MARK
What do you think we should do? CHERYL
It's not we, it's you, Mark. It's up to you. MARK
I want to know how you feel. CHERYL
That doesn't come in to it. MARK
Yes, it does. I don't just write poems to anyone. CHERYL
Mark, what do you want me to say? How much I was touched by that? How special this has been to me? Is that going to help you? No, it's going to make things worse. MARK
You mean to say, come the sixth session that will be it? CHERYL
Yes, that will be it. I explained that the first time we met. Mark has a serious and painful moment. CHERYL (CONT'D)
I'm sorry. If it's any consolation, it's also hard for me to think about it. MARK
Then maybe we should pull the plug now. CHERYL
I think maybe we should. It's only going to get harder. I guess you might as well save the money. Maybe buy yourself a nice futon. A LITTLE LATER.
Cheryl is getting dressed. Mark watches pensively. She pa and looks at him. He keeps a brave face. There is a knock the door.
Just a moment. She and Mark make eye contact for the last time. They man to smile at each other.
I desperately wanted to feel that because of Cheryl, my life had changed. But it hadn't. Apart from her usual things, she is also carrying a long mirror.
Bye, Mark
Bye. As Cheryl goes out, Vera comes in.
Everything all right?
He did great. See you. I'm sorry, I have to run.
See you. Vera walks in and closes the door behind her.

150 Cheryl goes to her car and opens the trunk. As she is put the mirror inside, the Chinese clerk, who is showing a CO to their room, gives her an odd look. Cheryl takes no not gets in her car and starts the engine. Just then, Vera runs up and taps on her window. The windo winds down. Vera hands Cheryl an envelope with money in i At first, Cheryl just looks at it, then realizes what it
You forgot this. Cheryl smiles.
I knew there was a reason I came here today. Vera waves goodbye as she goes and Cheryl sits contemplat the envelope in her lap. Then she tosses it onto the dash drives away.

head_text.subj: EXT. STREET OUTSIDE MARK'S PLACE. DAY

text: 151 Vera wheels Mark home. They travel in silence.
152 Father Brendan and Mark are together in the chapel.
I felt I'd just been through a ceremony that I didn't know the meaning of. I kept thinking, is that all there is? Just an empty hole at the end of it? A bigger hole than there was before?
I'm sorry Mark, you can't always trust your feelings. You've achieved a great thing. It may take you a while to realize that. Time passes.
153 It is a moonlit night. On the opposite wall from the Virg Mary is a picture of Amanda and Mark. Mark lies in his ir lung staring at it.

I wrote letters to Amanda in Germany. Five, six pages long A year passed, Heard nothing. Was it my fault? Of course it was. But the guilt isn't enough to patch over the rage. I pound the insides of my mind with words, such puny fists, And nobody hears.

The poem ends and we hear instead a RADIO BROADCAST of a Giants' game. Mark is engrossed. Suddenly the broadcast stops. The digital read-out on the clock radio, which say 12:57, disappears. A street light, visible through the window, goes out. The electric pump under Mark's iron lun whirrs to a halt. We hear the sound of air escaping, then eerie silence. Even the cat is motionless. For a few moments, Mark seems hypnotized. Then, he twists head and clamps onto his mouth stick. He manoeuvres it ov to the speaker button on the phone and manages to press i the semi-darkness. We hear a dial tone.
154 There is an answering machine on a bedside table.
Hi, this is Rod. Leave a message, or not.
Rod, it's Mark. I need help. The power's gone out, including the pump on the iron lung. I'd say I've got about three hours before I start to turn blue. I hope you get this in time.
155 Mark winces in frustration.
Okay... nine-one-one. He swings the mouth stick over to the 9 button. As he pre it, he loses his grip and the mouth stick falls to the fl
Shit! At first, he seems panicky, but after a few moments he be to control his breathing and gradually psyches himself in strange calm.
So this is how it ends. Time passes. We see Mark from a high angle. More time pas We see Mark's face as he slips into unconsciousness.

156 Cheryl enters the room wrapped in a white, terry cloth ro The room is dominated by a small, beautifully tiled immer pool with a hand rail and steps. The MIKVAH LADY gets up her chair and approaches her.
Is this your first time?
Yes, it is. I'm converting. She takes off her robe and hands it to the Mikvah Lady, w does not fail to notice Cheryl's body.
So, what do you do? Cheryl closes her eyes and thinks for a moment.
I don't think you'd understand.
You can try me.
Okay. I'm a housewife.
Why shouldn't I understand?
I guess I was mistaken. Cheryl steps towards the pool.
I see you're very comfortable with being naked. She takes hold of the rail and puts her foot in the water
That has never been one of my problems.
Sometimes new brides come with their mothers. Do I have to take this off? Can I please leave this on? They've never been naked before. No honey, it all has to come off.
And it does? Cheryl takes another step into the water.

And it does. They stand on the edge of that pool without anything to cling to but themselves. Nothing to hide behind. This is your body. This is the body that God crafted for you. Cheryl immerses herself up to her chest.

Immerse completely. Go completely under the water, without touching the walls or anything. She immerses completely. We see her under the water. She hears a voice in the distance, her own voice. At the same time, there is a look of elation in her eyes.
Okay Mark, you can open your eyes now.
157 Mark is on the bed alone. He opens his eyes.

This is your body. A few feet in front of Mark, Cheryl is holding a full-len mirror. The angle is such that he can see all of himself. is mesmerized by his own image. Flashes of light from the mirror flicker over his face.
So this is the body that someone was able to love. Not quite as bad as I thought.
158 Overhead fluorescent lights flash by, as we observe the ceiling from Mark's point of view. We also hear the sound rapidly rolling rubber wheels, and a voice.
Mark, can you hear me? Open your eyes.
159 Mark is in a regular hospital bed, with a temporary plast cocoon over him in place of his iron lung. There is a volunteer called SUSAN in the room with him.
They'll be letting you go today. Whoever looks after you will leave the portable respirator switched on at night, fully charged, so you'll have at least one back-up system.
How close was I?
To what?
You know, to that tunnel thing and the light, and the voice saying don't go near the light.
Is that what you remember?
No. I assume I passed out. Before that, I remember feeling sorry for myself.
Do you feel relieved now?
No. I mean, I'm relieved that Rod got to me in time, but I still feel sorry for myself.
I'm sure there's a cure for that. Would you like to talk to someone?
I feel comfortable talking to you.
I'm only a volunteer, not a therapist. I can refer you to someone if you like. Mark breaks into a broad smile, then a chuckle.
I'm sorry, I don't mean to be rude. I'm just smiling at the idea that a therapist could do anything useful for me right now. My priest couldn't.
Are you religious?
Yes. I would find it absolutely intolerable not to be able to blame someone for all this. Are you?
No, I don't go to any church and I don't think about God very much. But I believe there's a mysterious logic, or poetry to life. I guess that makes me a spiritual type.
Yes, that would count.
Would you like me to visit you?
Are you married?
No.
Do you have a steady boyfriend?
No.
Then please visit as often as you can.
She smiles. Mark is loaded into an ambulance.
Bye. Take care.
There's just one more thing I want to tell you.
She gets into the ambulance and squats down next to him.
I'm not a virgin. She looks genuinely pleased to hear it.
So, are you in a relationship at the moment?
No, it was a passing thing. The driver is ready to shut the doors.
Thanks for sharing that with me. She gets out of the ambulance and waves.
161 Mark is accompanied by an AMBULANCE OFFICER. We see clear blue sky through the back windows. The sun shines in and warms Mark's face. He closes his eyes in contentment.
Nice day, isn't it?
The best.
Good to be alive, huh?
162 We see the disappearing figure of Susan from the point of view of the departing ambulance.

I met Susan five years before I died. She was the love of my life. We had the same priorities, baseball pretty much came first, and we wrote each other mushy poems. I never expected it, nor did she, but that's often the way things turn out.
163 Rod shows Father Brendan into Mark's room.
Father Brendan sits in a chair next to Mark's iron lung. FATHER BRENDAN
That was quite something. What do you propose to do for an encore? MARK
Yep, I almost found out the big secret. But here I am, back with the living. If there is another place, then I think they took one look at me and decided to throw me back. FATHER BRENDAN
And welcome back. MARK
And thank you for coming to visit. FATHER BRENDAN
I know it's been awhile since we talked about this... About Cheryl. At the time, you seemed to feel so badly about her... or about it? MARK
I no longer feel like that. Father Brendan is rather taken by surprise. FATHER BRENDAN
Oh? That's good to hear. In the end, you're glad that you did it? MARK
Yes, I am. In fact, at this point in time, I feel very blessed. FATHER BRENDAN
Blessed? MARK
Yes, blessed. They put me on this new anti-depressant and now I can really see life from the cup half full rather than cup half empty point of view. Father Brendan looks truly amazed.
MARK (CONT'D)
It takes about six weeks to kick in, but when it does, you can really tell the difference. FATHER BRENDAN
Hey, that's great. Mark grins. MARK
I'm pulling your leg, Father. I'm not on drugs. I have a girlfriend. FATHER BRENDAN
You're kidding me. A real girlfriend? MARK
A very real girlfriend. She adores me. She'll do anything for me. And I can get pretty kinky sometimes, believe you me. Her name is Susan. FATHER BRENDAN
I'm flabbergasted. Is she pretty? MARK
She sure is. FATHER BRENDAN
Has she got a sister? MARK
As a matter of fact... FATHER BRENDAN
I'm kidding. MARK
No, you're not. Anyway, we're starting a publishing company together. Father Brendan smiles and shakes his head. FATHER BRENDAN
Here I was, all prepared to offer comfort to the forlorn - that's supposed to be my specialty - and now I can just throw away that little speech. MARK
No, no. Please make the little speech. I'd love to hear it. 89A.
Okay, but I'll try and keep it short.
Don't make it too short.
Okay, fine. Here goes. The meaning of love. Love is a journey.
I already like it.
There is a pause.
That's it. That's all of I've got. I told you it's short. Love is a journey.
Mark laughs.
164 Father Brendan lets himself out and walks back the way he came. There is definitely a smile on his face.
165 Mark also has a smile on his face as he lies awake.

Actually, I was on drugs, I was taking anti-depressants and they were helping a bit. At least I was able to see the cup-of-life metaphor as a useful tool. Of course, the two halves were never even. Not in my case, that's for sure. Look at all the years of unendurable crap I've had to put up with. That fills most of the cup. But in the little bit that's left, what do I have to show for myself? Journalism? Poetry? At the very least, three beautiful women who all loved me and will all show up at my funeral.
166 Josh saunters out to the mail box. He retrieves the mail, sifts through it and pauses over a letter. He is tempted open it, but thinks better of it.
167 Cheryl is planting stuff in the back yard. Josh approache her with the letter.
It's from a Susan Fernbach.
She takes it and opens it uncertainly, somehow anticipati its contents.
168 A full-blown Catholic funeral is happening. Meaningful hu are exchanged. Eyes are dabbed. We hear Mark's voice.

Three Reasons to Live The mundane: O God, it was boring, but I did it got it out of the way The transcendent: We had this agreement -- God gave me life for a while I gave Him gratitude for a while and it worked out OK The curious: You know how every day is different? I just wanted to see what would happen next
169 Father Brendan delivers a eulogy. We see members of Mark' FAMILY, all teary-eyed.
Mark, I know you're watching. I'm sorry, my friend, but we have to do this. Just bear with me, and I think you might like it.

I've been branching out lately, reading Native American stories about the character of the trickster. Sometimes he shows up as a coyote, sometimes as a raven, but he always does the unexpected. The trickster breaks the rules. Mark O'Brien, whose life we're celebrating today, was very much the trickster -- anyone who knew him knew that.

Besides his irreverent humor and alarming honesty, he always did the unexpected. In nearly every aspect of his life, Mark did the unexpected. His was a dynamic voice in a paralyzed body, a full life lived long after he should have been dead. He graduated from college, wrote and published articles and poems, and -- against all odds, by his own admission -- entered into the fully human experience of physical love. In this way, Mark lived from day to day to day, from breath to breath to breath, for 49 years. He loved, and he was loved and in his quiet voice, he spoke loud truths.
We see Rod, Vera and Laura the therapist in various rows. Also Amanda, holding a toddler in her arms and sitting ne to a tall, boring-looking HUSBAND.
Susan Fernbach will now read one of Mark's favorite poems.
This is called Love Poem for No One in Particular. We see SUSAN at the lectern, reading from a book.

Let me touch you with my words. For my hands lie limp as empty gloves. Let my words stroke your hair, Slide down your back and tickle your belly. For my hands, light and free-flying as bricks, Ignore my wishes and stubbornly refuse to carry out my quietest desires. We see Cheryl, as deeply touched by the words as she was first time.
Let my words enter your mind, bearing torches. Admit them willingly into your being So they may caress you gently within.

170 In the middle of the room, moonlit, is Mark's iron lung, empty and majestic, with the cat sitting on top. As we mo around the eerie capsule, we hear the sound of the French Can slowly fade up. It continues over END CREDITS.
